class_notes:
(Same as HIST 585-4)


Topic: "Writing Resistance | This course will explore some of the ways that writers and thinkers have understood, defined, and tried to represent "resistance" in their work from refusing the confines of established categories; to rethinking how we define and use existing archives; to revisioning concepts of agency, community, and courage; to revisiting what we think of as the locus and/or impetus of revolutionary action. Materials will be selected from a broad range of materials across historical moments and national cultures. Selections will be made from among, but not limited to, the following: Sophocles' '"Antigone" and its staging by the Theater of War production; Charlotte Delbo, Convoy to Auschwitz: Women of the French Resistance; Vaclav Havel, Living in Truth; Jose Mu√±oz, Cruising Utopia; Assia Djebar, Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade; Lauren Berlant et al., "The Feeltank Manifesto": Dev Hochberg, Becoming Palestine: Toward an Archival Imagination of the Future; T.W. Adorno, "On Foreign Words"; Edward Said, Representations of the Intellectual; Svetlana Alexievich, Voices from Chernobyl; Eduardo Galeano, Memory of Fire; Mahasveta Devi, "Draupadi." Participants in the seminar will be invited to contribute an additional work of their own choosing to our shared consideration.
course_description: This course focuses on a specific body of literary texts, critical approach, or theoretical problem in the area of Comparative Literature.  Students may repeat this course for credit if the subject matter varies.
